sen.j: 坊官（ぼうかん・房官）とは、平安時代以後に寺院の最高指導者（別当・三綱）などの家政を担当した機関及びそこに属した僧侶のこと。
sen.e: Bokan (坊官 or 房官) is an organization which was in charge of the household management of the supreme leader of a temple (e.g. betto (administrator of a Buddhist temple) or sango (three monastic positions with management roles at a temple)) or the monks who belonged to such an organization in and after the Heian period.

sen.cmt: (坊官 or 房官) を削除しました。カッコ内を修正しました。

sen.j: 俗世の政所に相当する。
sen.e: Bokan is similar to the Mandokoro (Administrative Board) in the everyday world.

sen.j: 寺院内のおいて僧侶が住む空間を僧房（僧坊）と呼んだ。
sen.e: Living quarters used by monks in a temple were called sobo (僧房 or 僧坊).

sen.j: 特に別当や三綱が居住する僧房内において身の回りの世話や事務の補助を行う僧侶を坊官（房官）と称した。
sen.e: Especially the monks who were in charge of personal cares and assisting clerical works of betto or sango at the sobo used by the betto or sango were called bokan.

sen.j: 後に別当（寺院における別当とは別のもの）以下、勾当・預 (官職)などの公家や武家の政所の同様の役職が派生するようになった。
sen.e: Later, in mondokoro for court nobles and samurai families began to have similar positions such as betto (chief administrator) (betto here is different position from that in Buddhist temples), koto (a secretary) or azukari (an additional post to the chief of Naizenshi).

sen.j: 特に皇族や公家の子弟が門跡として入るようになると、寺院の要職はこうした門跡による継承によって固定化された。
sen.e: Especially when the young people in the Imperial family or court nobles began to join temples as monzeki (successor of a temple), important posts came to be succeeded by these monzeki.

sen.j: 門跡に近侍する僧侶を坊官と呼ぶようになった。
sen.e: Then the monks who serve monzeki came to be called bokan.

sen.j: 門跡は三綱以下の人事権を掌握して自己近侍の坊官を補任した。
sen.e: Monzeki took control of the personnel matters of sango and lower rank monks, and appointed bokan who would serve himself.

sen.j: 更に永宣旨による権限を行使して、本来ならば一定の資格を必要とする法橋・法眼・法印などの僧官を彼らに与えてその忠誠を確保した。
sen.e: In addition, monzeki exercised their right under Eisenji (decree allowing certain rights permanently) and granted sokan (official positions given to Buddhist priests by Imperial Court) such as hokkyo (the third highest rank for Buddhist priests), hogen (the second highest rank for Buddhist priests) or Hoin (the highest rank in the order of priesthood) to such bokan to secure their loyalty.

sen.j: 江戸時代に入ると、門跡の公家化が進んだ。
sen.e: In the Edo period, more and more monzeki became court nobles.

sen.j: 近侍の僧侶でも最上級のもののみを坊官と呼び、以下を諸大夫・北面・侍などと公家と同様の家臣形成をしていくようになる。
sen.e: Therefore, only the monks who served monzeki and were in the highest rank came to be called bokan and other lower rank monks came to be categorized into shodaibu, hokumen or samurai; such categorization formed a hierarchy similar to that of court nobles.
